#Text=CHAPTER III .
#Text=THE SLAVE-SPECULATOR
#Text=DICK JENNINGS the slave-speculator , was one of the few Northern men , who go to the South and throw aside their honest mode of obtaining a living and resort to trading in human beings .
#Text=A more repulsive-looking person could scarcely be found in any community of bad looking men .
#Text=Tall , lean and lank , with high cheek-bones , face much pitted with the small-pox , gray eyes with red eyebrows , and sandy whiskers , he indeed stood alone without mate or fellow in looks .
#Text=Jennings prided himself upon what he called his goodness of heat , and was always speaking of his humanity .

#Text=As many of the slaves whom he intended taking to the New Orleans market had been raised in Richmond , and had relations there , he determined to leave the city early in the morning , so as not to witness any of the scenes so common on the departure of a slave-gang to the far South .
#Text=In this , he was most successful ; for not even Isabella , who had called at the prison several times to see her mother and sister , was aware of the time that they were to leave .
#Text=The slave-trader started at early dawn , and was beyond the confines of the city long before the citizens were out of their beds .
#Text=As a slave regards a life on the sugar , cotton , or rice plantation as even worse than death , they are ever on the watch for an opportunity to escape .
#Text=The trader , aware of this , secures his victims in chains before he sets out on his journey .
#Text=On this occasion , Jennings had the men chained in pairs , while the women were allowed to go unfastened , but were closely watched .
#Text=After a march of eight days , the company arrived on the banks of the Ohio River , where they took a steamer for the place of their destination .

#Text=Jennings had already advertised in the New Orleans papers , that he would be there with a prime lot of able-bodied slaves , men and women , fit for field-service , with a few extra ones calculated for house-servants , -- all between the ages of fifteen and twenty-five years ; but like most men who make a business of speculating in human beings , he often bought many who were far advanced in years , and would try to pass them off for five or six years younger than they were .
#Text=Few persons can arrive at anything approaching the real age of the negro , by mere observation , unless they are well acquainted with the race .
#Text=Therefore , the slave-trader frequently carried out the deception with perfect impunity .

#Text=After the steamer had left the wharf and was fairly out on the bosom of the broad Mississippi , the speculator called his servant Pompey to him ; and instructed him as to getting the negroes ready for market .
#Text=Among the forty slaves that the trader had on this occasion , were some whose appearance indicated that they had seen some years and had gone through considerable service .
#Text=Their gray hair and whiskers at once pronounced them to be above the ages set down in the trader 's advertisement .

#Text=Pompey had long been with Jennings , and understood his business well , and if he did not take delight in the discharge of his duty , he did it at least with a degree of alacrity , so that he might receive the approbation of his master .
#Text=Pomp , as he was usually called by the trader , was of real negro blood , and would often say , when alluding to himself , “ Dis nigger am no counterfeit , he is de ginuine artikle .
#Text=Dis chile is none of your haf-and-haf , dere is no bogus about him . ”

#Text=Pompey was of low stature , round face , and , like most of his race , had a set of teeth , which , for whiteness and beauty , could not be surpassed ; his eyes were large , lips thick , and hair short and woolly .

#Text=Pompey had been with Jennings so long , and had seen so much of buying and selling of his fellow-creatures , that he appeared perfectly indifferent to the heart-rending scenes which daily occurred in his presence .
#Text=Such is the force of habit : --
#Text=“ Vice is a monster of such frightful mien , That to be hated , needs but to be seen ; But seen too oft , familiar with its face , We first endure , then pity , then embrace . ”
#Text=It was on the second day of the steamer 's voyage , that Pompey selected five of the oldest slaves , took them into a room by themselves , and commenced preparing them for the market .
#Text=“ Now , ” said he , addressing himself to the company , “ I is de chap dat is to get you ready for de Orleans market , so dat you will bring marser a good price .
#Text=How old is you ? ” addressing himself to a man not less than forty .
#Text=“ If I live to see next sweet-potato-digging time , I shall be either forty or forty-five , I do n't know which . ”
#Text=“ Dat may be , ” replied Pompey ;
#Text=“ but now you is only thirty years old , -- dat 's what marser says you is to be . ”
#Text=“ I know I is more den dat , ” responded the man .
#Text=“ I ca n't help nuffin ' about dat , ” returned Pompey ;
#Text=“ but when you get into de market and any one ax you how old you is , and you tell um you is forty or forty-five , marser will tie you up and cut you all to pieces .
#Text=But if you tell um dat you is only thirty , den he wo n't .
#Text=Now remember dat you is thirty years old and no more . ”
